You make a lot of sense. I am an identical twin. My attachment to my brother was very strong but superficial as we grew up in a family where not much was talked about. Our individual identities were neglected to the point that our relatives often treated us as a unit, the twins. As I grew up, I became more aware of the need to be myself, and while a strong attachment to a twin sibling can be tremendously positive it also has many drawbacks. Freeing myself from the negative dimensions of that attachment and becoming myself has been a lifelong and very rewarding pursuit. Godspeed!

driving can be pretty nerve wracking in the beginning. i unfortunately was in a pretty nasty car accident with my mom when i was 17 and it caused major anxiety when i finally got my license at 18. it was def heightened by the fact that a majority of my driving i ended up doing for the following few years was just to my part time job and back, which was only a three minute drive away, so i really didn't have a lot of experience on highways and busy cities. bUt, i'm almost 22 now and i feel a lot better, bot perfect and i still have bouts of anxiety, but i've since taken a few lone, long trips by myself and continuing to step out of my comfort zone a bit when driving has helped.   i'm sure it can be difficult when you're the only one of your siblings that has a license, automatically placing u in the position of driving them places, but don't be scared or feel selfish for taking even tiny trips by yourself.

(Hey! 9 min in and I guess you realized it too!) ğŸ˜„  Suggestions: As someone who doesn't know you and has no loyalties to gas you up, I think you should consider making your videos shorter. Like have a timer set that you try to stick to. Maybe about 10 min. It will help with your anxiety because there won't be as much pressure to perform/be entertaining for an indefinite amount of time. It'll also help you stay focused.  And this way, even if you do decide to talk aimlessly about nothing- which is fine, it won't go on for 20 minutes, making you feel boring, and making your new, personally developed audience leave early. Then, maybe extend the time as necessary when you have a specific topic that requires the extra time. It'll be easier to keep up maintaining your channel as well, if you create a reasonable and consistent time for yourself. Less to come up with. Less to edit. And when you look back on what you did, you won't just feel like you're rambling for too long, so you'll be more likely to continue, because you'll feel better about the final result.

I have 4 sister's and I'm the middle child and I relate to so much of what you said about in the majority of what was in this video. All of my sisters are loud and outgoing and it's the same situation where it's like I get interrupted and talked over so I end up just not saying much, so when I've been by myself I've made car videos before years ago cuz I was doing it to be in contact with a friend of mine who lived in another state. It was really strange to be able to have my voice be the only one out loud. I also have it where I end up being so distracted I don't finish my thoughts. Some people are very excited and outgoing so they're ready to just let their thoughts and ideas out and be heard, so when you have a lot of interruptions you tend to have more thoughts just kept in your head and speaking them just feels really strange and almost abnormal to do so. I feel a lot of the times being distracted is a way of you just repeating the patterns of being interrupted if that makes sense.
